questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of bloating and nausea after eating. During this time, he has also had episodic abdominal pain, which increases after meals. He has osteoarthritis of the left knee. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is ibuprofen. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 21 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft; there is mild tenderness to palpation over the epigastrium. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows 3 shallow ulcers of the gastric mucosa. The biopsy specimen shows chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa and Helicobacter pylori. The physician prescribes a 2-week course of antibiotics and omeprazole to treat the H. pylori infection and recommends that the patient avoid drinking alcohol and using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Five weeks later, the patient returns to the office for a follow-up examination. He feels well. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the success of treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A urea breath test is indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication 4–6 weeks after completing treatment. Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole) should be stopped at least 2 weeks before testing because they increase the risk of false negative results. Other tests for confirming eradication include stool antigen testing and rapid urease testing of biopsy samples. The latter is only considered in patients who require follow-up endoscopy (e.g., those with persistent symptoms, dysplasia on biopsy, new onset of symptoms after successful eradication). Acid suppression medications can be discontinued after eradication is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of increasing antibiotic resistance, eradication should be confirmed in all patients who have been treated for an H. pylori infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Because endoscopic follow-up with biopsy (for rapid urease testing) is an invasive procedure, it is only indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication in certain patients with peptic ulcer disease (e.g., to rule out gastric cancer in those with refractory symptoms). This patient should undergo a less invasive procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool testing can be used to confirm H. pylori eradication. However, a stool antigen assay rather than a stool culture is indicated. Stool cultures have no role in the management of H. pylori infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing detects IgG antibodies against H. pylori. However, a positive test cannot distinguish between a past and a current infection. Moreover, because H. pylori antibodies may still be present for weeks or months after treatment and eradication, serologic testing has no utility in confirming the success of treatment.
questions.hint: This patient has peptic ulcer disease associated with H. pylori infection, which is being treated with H. pylori eradication therapy. Antibiotic resistance and/or inadequate adherence can lead to treatment failure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of upper abdominal pain and nausea that occurs about 3 hours after eating and at night. The symptoms improve with eating. After eating, he often has a feeling of fullness and bloating. He has had several episodes of dark stools over the past month. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks 2–3 12-oz bottles of beer on most weekdays. He takes no medications. He is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows epigastric tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Which of the following interventions is most likely to be effective in improving this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and alcohol consumption
Tetracycline, metronidazole, bismuth, and omeprazole therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cessation of smoking and alcohol consumption is an important adjunct to treat dyspepsia due to gastritis, pancreatic disorders, and PUD but is not the most effective measure to treat a duodenal ulcer, the majority of which are due to H. pylori infection (especially in individuals who are not taking NSAIDs).

B) CORRECT:

The vast majority of duodenal ulcers are caused by an underlying H. pylori infection (especially in individuals who are not taking NSAIDs). H. pylori eradication therapy (e.g., optimized bismuth quadruple therapy) heals > 90% of duodenal ulcers and prevents further complications, such as rebleeding, perforation, fistulation, and gastric outlet obstruction. This patient should also be counseled on smoking cessation and restricting alcohol intake, as both are important in preventing recurrence.

Clarithromycin triple therapy can be used to treat clarithromycin-sensitive H. pylori infection if first-line treatment is unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

Cholecystectomy would prevent symptoms due to gallstone disease, which can cause dyspeptic symptoms and for which obesity is a risk factor. However, melena would not be expected with gallstone disease, and the abdominal pain due to gallstone disease typically occurs postprandially rather than on an empty stomach and is most commonly localized to the right upper quadrant.

D) INCORRECT:

Exercise and weight loss are effective in improving the symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or hiatus hernia (HH). Patients with GERD or HH can report an aggravation of symptoms at night (due to the recumbent position) but these conditions typically manifest with heartburn and regurgitation. Epigastric pain and GI bleeding are atypical symptoms of GERD or HH. Lifestyle modifications such as exercise and weight loss should be recommended to this patient but are not the most effective measures to treat symptoms due to a duodenal ulcer.

E) INCORRECT:

Acid suppression therapy with a proton pump inhibitor such as pantoprazole is the treatment of choice for H. pylori-negative PUD. However, most duodenal ulcers are related to H. pylori infection (especially in individuals who are not taking NSAIDs). Although monotherapy with pantoprazole might temporarily improve this patient's symptoms, a different approach is more likely to be effective for providing long-term symptom relief and preventing further complications of the disease.
questions.hint: Dyspeptic symptoms (e.g., epigastric pain, bloating) and melena are features of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Epigastric pain that occurs on an empty stomach (e.g., at night, 2–5 hours after meals) and is relieved by eating (leading to weight gain) suggests a duodenal ulcer.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 30-year-old man reports a 6-month history of intermittent, burning epigastric pain without retrosternal radiation. The pain occurs daily and is associated with abdominal fullness and nausea. The patient reports no heartburn, vomiting, weight loss, rectal bleeding, or difficulty swallowing. He does not take any regular medications or over-the-counter medications such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs. He has no family history of gastrointestinal malignancies.
On examination, he appears well. His abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. There is no cervical, supraclavicular, inguinal, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The liver and spleen are not enlarged.
Complete blood count results include a leukocyte count of 5300 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), a hematocrit of 43.0% (41.0–53.0), and a platelet count of 250,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is not likely to provide useful information in the evaluation of uncomplicated dyspepsia.

B) INCORRECT:

Current joint guidelines from the American College of Gastroenterology and the Canadian Association of Gastroenterology recommend upper endoscopy for evaluation of dyspepsia in patients aged ≥60 years. They no longer recommend diagnostic endoscopy in patients <60 years of age who have so-called alarm features, such as weight loss or vomiting. Notably, this recommendation is conditional, because some patients — such as those with prominent symptoms (e.g., weight loss >9 kg or rapidly progressive dysphagia) or a family history of upper gastrointestinal cancer — will be at higher risk than others, such as patients with vomiting alone.

C) INCORRECT:

Prior guidelines recommended empiric PPI therapy without testing for H. pylori infection if the prevalence of H. pylori in the population was low (i.e., <15%), but this approach is no longer recommended because of the difficulty of accurately establishing the prevalence of infection in a given population.

D) INCORRECT:

In the evaluation of dyspepsia, barium radiography is less accurate than endoscopy and does not allow for biopsies to be performed.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms are classic for dyspepsia, which is typically diagnosed when patients present with at least one month of epigastric pain. The pain may be described as burning and is sometimes associated with bothersome postprandial fullness or early satiation. Dyspepsia is sometimes also associated with heartburn or even nausea and vomiting, but the epigastric discomfort is the predominant symptom. Dyspepsia needs to be distinguished from gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is characterized by regurgitation and retrosternal (rather than epigastric) burning pain and is managed differently from dyspepsia.

Joint guidelines from the American College of Gastroenterology and the Canadian Association of Gastroenterology recommend different approaches to evaluating dyspepsia depending on whether the patient is older or younger than 60 years of age.

• Patients < 60 years old (as in this case) should undergo testing for Helicobacter pylori and be treated if the test result is positive. This test-and-treat strategy is thought to be beneficial and cost-effective relative to empiric treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).
• Patients ≥ 60 years old should undergo upper endoscopy.

H. pylori testing should be performed with either a stool antigen test or a carbon-13 urea breath test. (Serologic testing for H. pylori is not recommended because of a low positive predictive value.) If the test result is negative or if the patient does not improve after H. pylori treatment, then empiric treatment with a PPI, such as omeprazole, is recommended.

Key learning point: In a patient <60 years of age who has dyspepsia, the first step in evaluation is to test for Helicobacter pylori and then treat if the test result is positive.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports 6 weeks of burning epigastric discomfort that generally develops after a large meal and lasts for 2 to 3 hours. She tried an over-the-counter antacid (calcium carbonate) but did not notice an improvement. She has not lost any weight and reports no melena, passage of bright-red blood, or vomiting. She takes no regular medications.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Which one of the following next steps is recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Empiric triple therapy with lansoprazole, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin without testing for Helicobacter pylori infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Noninvasive testing for Helicobacter pylori infection — with either a urea breath test or a fecal antigen detection test — is recommended for patients with new-onset dyspepsia who are younger than 60 years of age. Serologic testing for H. pylori infection is a less accurate indicator of current infection than urea breath testing or stool antigen testing. The urea breath test is most accurate when the patient has been off any proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for at least 2 weeks.

Empiric treatment for H. pylori infection is not recommended; treatment is warranted only if the test result is positive. Current guidelines also do not recommend empiric treatment with PPIs until H. pylori infection has been ruled out.

Key learning point: Patients younger than 60 years of age with new-onset uncomplicated dyspepsia should be evaluated with noninvasive testing (urea breath test or fecal antigen detection) for Helicobacter pylori infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment for H. pylori infection is not recommended; treatment is warranted only if the test result is positive. Current guidelines also do not recommend empiric treatment with PPIs until H. pylori infection has been ruled out.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is appropriate for patients with new-onset dyspepsia who are ≥60 years of age. The American College of Gastroenterology no longer recommends diagnostic endoscopy in patients <60 years of age who have alarm symptoms, such as vomiting or weight loss alone. Notably, this recommendation is conditional, because some patients — such as those with prominent symptoms (e.g., weight loss >9 kg or rapidly progressive dysphagia) or a family history of upper gastrointestinal cancer — will be at higher risk than others, such as patients with vomiting alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for celiac disease could be considered if the patient reported any of the typical features of this disease, such as diarrhea, flatulence, borborygmus, and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH probe testing is not recommended for initial evaluation of dyspepsia because of its low sensitivity and specificity for detecting H. pylori infection as part of a test-and-treat strategy.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man reports a 12-week history of epigastric discomfort that has been unresponsive to a 2-week course of over-the-counter proton pump inhibitor therapy. The patient has no family history of gastric cancer, current use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, weight loss, or gastrointestinal bleeding. Deep palpation of the abdomen reveals epigastric tenderness. The presentation prompts concern for Helicobacter pylori infection.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Endoscopic biopsy with urease testing after proton pump inhibitors have been discontinued for 2 weeks
Helicobacter pylori serology after proton pump inhibitors have been discontinued for 2 weeks
Helicobacter pylori urea breath test without discontinuing proton-pump-inhibitor therapy
Helicobacter pylori fecal antigen test after proton pump inhibitors have been discontinued for 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy is recommended for evaluation of dyspepsia only in patients aged ≥ 60 years. An upper endoscopy can also be considered in younger patients whose symptoms persist after H. pylori eradication and adequate trials of PPIs, tricyclic antidepressants, and prokinetic agents.

B) INCORRECT:

H. pylori serology may be useful in ruling out infection, given its high negative predictive value, but it is the least accurate of the noninvasive testing options.

C) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy is recommended for evaluation of dyspepsia only in patients aged ≥60 years. An upper endoscopy can also be considered in younger patients whose symptoms persist after H. pylori eradication and adequate trials of PPIs, tricyclic antidepressants, and prokinetic agents.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients <60 years of age who present with uncomplicated dyspepsia should undergo noninvasive testing for Helicobacter pylori infection with the fecal antigen or urea breath test. However, patients should not undergo these tests while receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine-2 (H2) receptor antagonists, or antimicrobial therapy, because those treatments can suppress infection and thereby reduce test sensitivity.

E) CORRECT:

Patients <60 years of age who present with uncomplicated dyspepsia should undergo noninvasive testing for Helicobacter pylori infection with the fecal antigen or urea breath test. Both tests perform with >95% sensitivity and specificity. However, patients should not undergo these tests while receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine-2 (H2) receptor antagonists, or antimicrobial therapy, because those treatments can suppress infection and thereby reduce test sensitivity. Diagnostic testing should be delayed 24 hours in patients taking H2-receptor antagonists, 2 weeks in those taking PPIs, and 4 weeks in those taking antimicrobials. If the testing for H. pylori returns positive, the patient should be treated with one of the treatment regimens for this organism, followed by repeat testing to confirm eradication.

An upper endoscopy is recommended for evaluation of dyspepsia only in patients aged ≥60 years. The American College of Gastroenterology no longer recommends diagnostic endoscopy in patients <60 years of age who have so-called alarm features, such as weight loss or vomiting. Notably, this recommendation is conditional, because some patients — such as those with prominent symptoms (e.g., weight loss >9 kg or rapidly progressive dysphagia) or a family history of upper gastrointestinal cancer — will be at higher risk than others, such as patients with vomiting alone. An upper endoscopy can also be considered in younger patients whose symptoms persist after H. pylori eradication and adequate trials of PPIs, tricyclic antidepressants, and prokinetic agents.

Key learning point: The most appropriate noninvasive tests to diagnose Helicobacter pylori infection in a young patient with uncomplicated dyspepsia are either an H. pylori fecal antigen test or an H. pylori urea breath test, performed 2 weeks after use of any proton pump inhibitor is discontinued.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college student with a history of irritable bowel syndrome and gastroesophageal reflux disease presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided abdominal pain. She reports several weeks of abdominal pain associated with constipation, as well as diffuse joint pain. She also reports a loss of more than 2 kg during the past few weeks, which she attributes to reduced oral intake because of the abdominal pain.
She is afebrile, her blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute. She is 167 cm tall and weighs 50 kg (BMI, 17.9). Abdominal examination does not reveal focal tenderness on palpation or any rebound or guarding; there is marked costovertebral angle tenderness on the left.
Nephrolithiasis is suspected. Urinalysis shows hematuria.

CT confirms a diagnosis of nephrolithiasis. Intravenous fluids and analgesia are initiated.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although all the options listed are causes of hypercalcemia, the milk-alkali syndrome is the most likely in this case because of the patient’s elevated phosphorus level and low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D level.

The milk-alkali syndrome is caused by ingestion of large amounts of calcium and absorbable alkali, with resulting hypercalcemia. It has become more common with increased use of calcium carbonate supplements. The milk-alkali syndrome can develop quickly and can lead to metastatic calcification and kidney failure.

The absorption of calcium in patients with this syndrome results in a suppressed level of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which leads to a reduction in renal phosphorus excretion. If milk (which contains a large amount of phosphorus) is the source of the excess calcium, patients with milk-alkali syndrome typically have an elevated phosphorus level. A more common source of calcium is antacid ingestion for abdominal discomfort; with this source of calcium, the phosphorus level may be low because of the absence of a large phosphate load and because calcium carbonate can bind phosphorus in the intestine and prevent its absorption. This patient’s elevated phosphorus level suggests that she has been treating her abdominal discomfort with ingestion of milk and antacids.

The low PTH level also leads to decreased 1-alpha hydroxylation of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and, therefore, to low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels.

Patients with eating disorders are particularly susceptible to developing the milk-alkali syndrome. Hypovolemia stimulates both bicarbonate and calcium reabsorption at the proximal tubule, thereby exacerbating metabolic alkalosis from alkali ingestion.

Key learning point: Ingestion of excess calcium leads to phosphorus and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels that are high and low, respectively, relative to the normal ranges.

B) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis causes hypercalcemia by means of increased 1-alpha hydroxylation, such that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels would be high.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid carcinoma would cause elevated levels of PTH and, therefore, low phosphorus levels. Although hypophosphatemia could be masked by renal failure, there should not be low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels in the presence of elevated PTH and adequate 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid adenoma would cause elevated levels of PTH and, therefore, low phosphorus levels. Although hypophosphatemia could be masked by renal failure, there should not be low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels in the presence of elevated PTH and adequate 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels.

E) INCORRECT:

B-cell lymphoma causes hypercalcemia by means of increased 1-alpha hydroxylation, such that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels would be high.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man with a history of hypertension and gout has been at a rehabilitation facility for 6 months after undergoing surgery for a right hip fracture he sustained during a fall. His mobility has slowly improved with physical therapy, but he still requires significant assistance in walking and using the bathroom. During his stay at the facility, he has been weighed routinely and has unintentionally lost 8 kg, approximately 1.5 kg per month. He eats three meals per day but does not usually finish his meals. He reports feeling hungry before meals but becomes full shortly after he starts eating.
He lived alone before his fall, and when asked about his current experience, reports that he is happy and that the food is “pretty good.” He reports no heartburn, dysphagia, abdominal pain, nausea, chest pain, shortness of breath, or depression. He has a family history of coronary artery disease, and his mother had breast cancer at age 81.
His vital signs are normal except for his weight (71 kg, down from 79 kg 6 months ago). His physical examination is unremarkable except for decreased right leg length and decreased mobility of his right hip.
Laboratory testing reveals a hematocrit of 37% (reference range, 41–53), but the remainder of his complete blood count as well as his complete chemistry panel, thyroid-stimulating hormone level, and C-reactive protein level are all normal.
A chest and abdominal radiograph shows degenerative disk disease but is otherwise unremarkable. He had a colonoscopy at age 75, which showed one small hyperplastic polyp in the sigmoid colon.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography is not recommended in this setting. It may be useful in staging if a malignancy is diagnosed on esophagogastroduodenoscopy, but it is not recommended as a screening tool for patients with weight loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral nutritional supplementation is recommended for older adults with weight loss. However, appetite stimulants, such as megestrol acetate and the antidepressant mirtazapine, are not generally recommended in this setting because the benefits are unclear and there may be side effects.

C) CORRECT:

An involuntary weight loss of >5% of total body weight during a 6- to 12-month period should trigger evaluation, particularly in an older adult. This patient appears to have inadequate dietary intake, which is a common cause of weight loss and can be related to social issues (such as difficulty obtaining food), psychological factors (such as depression), medical causes (such as malignancy), and the physiology of aging.

Given this patient’s reported early satiety and mild anemia, the most appropriate next step is esophagogastroduodenoscopy to evaluate for gastric cancer, peptic ulcer disease, or another gastric pathology that could be causing his symptoms. This patient is relatively healthy and a reasonable candidate for an endoscopic procedure, but the risks associated with an invasive procedure requiring sedation should always be weighed against the benefits of intervention, particularly in older adults. CT of the chest and abdomen is another reasonable option for an older patient with unexplained weight loss and no localizing symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a relatively healthy older adult with involuntary weight loss, inadequate dietary intake, early satiety, and mild anemia is esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral nutritional supplementation is recommended for older adults with weight loss. However, appetite stimulants, such as megestrol acetate and the antidepressant mirtazapine, are not generally recommended in this setting because the benefits are unclear and there may be side effects. Mirtazapine may be considered in a patient with depression and unintentional weight loss, but this patient does not have depression.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not generally recommended for older adults with unexplained weight loss in the absence of localizing symptoms. In addition, this patient appears to be up to date on colorectal cancer screening.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man with a history of hypertension, depression, and osteoarthritis reports having epigastric abdominal pain for the past several weeks. The pain is constant but worst at mealtimes and is sharp and nonradiating. He has occasional nausea but reports no heartburn, emesis, chest pain, melena, hematochezia, or unintentional weight loss. He has no known drug allergies, and his home medications include daily amlodipine and sertraline, as well as naproxen, which he has been taking for the past 2 months because of knee pain.
His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for mild epigastric tenderness and a normal rectal examination with brown stool.
A complete blood count is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe a 2-week course of bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, metronidazole, and lansoprazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate is not a first-line agent for dyspepsia or NSAID-induced gastropathy. It can be used for treatment of a duodenal ulcer, but this condition would first need to be diagnosed by esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and nausea are common symptoms of gastroparesis, but this patient’s symptoms are more likely to be associated with the dyspepsia caused by NSAID use. Gastroparesis is less likely in this case, given the degree of abdominal pain, the long-term NSAID use, and the lack of risk factors for gastroparesis. Although some cases of gastroparesis are idiopathic, this patient has no known risk factors for delayed gastric emptying, such as diabetes or chronic opioid use. Furthermore, if gastroparesis were suspected, a gastric-emptying study would be recommended before any treatments, including metoclopramide, were initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

Current joint guidelines from the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) and the Canadian Association of Gastroenterology (CAG) recommend noninvasive Helicobacter pylori testing as the first step in evaluation for patients <60 years of age who have dyspepsia. Treatment of H. pylori infection — for example, with bismuth-based quadruple therapy (the combination of a PPI, bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole) — is warranted only if the test result is positive.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is recommended in all patients with dyspepsia who are aged 60 and older, to exclude malignancy. The ACG no longer recommends diagnostic endoscopy in patients under 60 years who have so-called alarm features, such as weight loss or vomiting. Notably, this recommendation is conditional, because some patients — such as those with prominent symptoms (e.g., weight loss >9 kg or rapidly progressive dysphagia) or a family history of upper gastrointestinal cancer — will be at higher risk than others, such as patients with vomiting alone.

E) CORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a common cause of dyspepsia (epigastric pain or burning, postprandial fullness, or some combination of these symptoms). NSAIDs can cause gastritis (inflammation), gastropathy (irritation without inflammation), and peptic ulcer disease. Gastropathy is more likely than peptic ulcer disease in this patient, given the normal rectal examination and normal blood count.

The first step in managing presumed NSAID-induced gastropathy is to discontinue the NSAID, if possible. If this is not possible, a histamine-2-receptor antagonist or proton pump inhibitor (PPI) may be added, although the benefits of this approach should be weighed against the potential risks of long-term PPI use, which include infection, malabsorption, and kidney disease. If the NSAID is stopped and the pain does not resolve, then a workup for dyspepsia should be initiated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial step for patients younger than 60 years of age who have dyspepsia while taking long-term NSAIDs is to discontinue the NSAID, if possible.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports having chronic abdominal pain for the past 6 months. The pain is epigastric, does not radiate, and is not associated with nausea, dysphagia, early satiety, weight loss, or blood in her stools. She has otherwise been healthy, and her social and family histories are unremarkable. She has no allergies, and her only medication is an oral contraceptive.
Her physical examination is notable for mild epigastric tenderness. A complete blood count is normal, and Helicobacter pylori stool antigen testing is negative.
A 2-month trial of a twice-daily proton pump inhibitor is completed but does not improve her symptoms. Subsequent evaluations with abdominal ultrasound and esophagogastroduodenoscopy, including gastric biopsies, are normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate a tricyclic antidepressant, to be taken daily at bedtime
Prescribe opioid analgesia, to be used only as needed for pain
Counsel the patient to consume meals at least 6 hours before going to bed
Begin a once-daily selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Functional (or nonulcer) dyspepsia is defined as dyspepsia that has no identifiable structural or organic cause. Current guidelines recommend evaluating for Helicobacter pylori infection in all patients — and obtaining an esophagogastroduodenoscopy in patients who are older than 60 years — to evaluate for etiology. Other tests, such as abdominal ultrasound, are not routinely recommended.

The pathophysiology of functional dyspepsia is not clear and may include visceral hypersensitivity. Some patients benefit from proton pump inhibitors, but if symptoms do not improve after an 8-week trial, the next step is to initiate a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). This recommendation is based on a systematic review of trials that involved TCA therapy in functional dyspepsia; although the evidence was judged as being of low quality, the results indicated that patients who took a TCA had a significant reduction in their dyspepsia symptoms compared with those taking placebo. In contrast, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors were no more effective than placebo.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in treatment for a healthy patient with functional dyspepsia who does not improve after 8 weeks of a proton pump inhibitor is to initiate a tricyclic antidepressant.

B) INCORRECT:

Opioids are not recommended in this situation, given their risks (including gastroparesis, constipation, and opioid-related bowel syndrome) and the lack of evidence for benefit in dyspepsia.

C) INCORRECT:

Probiotics have not been proven to be effective for functional dyspepsia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications for dyspepsia include avoiding causative foods, although no study has ever shown a conclusive association between diet and functional dyspepsia. Avoiding food before bedtime is important in managing gastroesophageal reflux disease but is not warranted in a patient with functional dyspepsia.

E) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors were no more effective than placebo in the treatment of functional dyspepsia.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. Five weeks ago, he was prescribed a 2-week course of antibiotics and omeprazole to treat the infection. He feels well. Which of the following is most appropriate for confirming treatment success?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A urea breath test is indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication 4–6 weeks after completing treatment. Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole) should be stopped at least 2 weeks before testing because they increase the risk of false negative results. Other tests for confirming eradication include stool antigen testing and rapid urease testing of biopsy samples. The latter is only considered in patients who require follow-up endoscopy (e.g., those with persistent symptoms, dysplasia on biopsy, new onset of symptoms after successful eradication). Acid suppression medications can be discontinued after eradication is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of increasing antibiotic resistance, eradication should be confirmed in all patients who have been treated for an H. pylori infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Because endoscopic follow-up with biopsy (for rapid urease testing) is an invasive procedure, it is only indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication in certain patients with peptic ulcer disease (e.g., to rule out gastric cancer in those with refractory symptoms). This patient should undergo a less invasive procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

E) INCORRECT:

Moreover, because H. pylori antibodies may still be present for weeks or months after treatment and eradication, serologic testing has no utility in confirming the success of treatment.

A 19-year-old female college student with a history of irritable bowel syndrome and gastroesophageal reflux disease presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided abdominal pain. She reports constipation, as well as diffuse joint pain. She also reports a loss of more than 2-kg (4.4-lb) during the past few weeks. Abdominal examination does not reveal focal tenderness on palpation or any rebound or guarding; there is marked costovertebral angle tenderness on the left. Urinalysis shows hematuria. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Creatinine

2.9 mg/dL


Calcium

12.4 mg/dL


Phosphate

4.8 mg/dL


25-hydroxyvitamin D
35 ng/mL (N = 30–80)


1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D
20 pg/mL (N = 25–45)


Parathyroid hormone
16 pg/mL


CT confirms a diagnosis of nephrolithiasis. Intravenous fluids and analgesia are initiated. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The milk-alkali syndrome is caused by ingestion of large amounts of calcium and absorbable alkali, with resulting hypercalcemia. The milk-alkali syndrome can develop quickly and can lead to metastatic calcification and kidney failure.

The absorption of calcium in patients with this syndrome results in a suppressed level of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which leads to a reduction in renal phosphorus excretion. If milk (which contains a large amount of phosphorus) is the source of the excess calcium, patients with milk-alkali syndrome typically have an elevated phosphorus level. A more common source of calcium is antacid ingestion for abdominal discomfort; with this source of calcium, the phosphorus level may be low because of the absence of a large phosphate load and because calcium carbonate can bind phosphorus in the intestine and prevent its absorption. This patient’s elevated phosphorus level suggests that she has been treating her abdominal discomfort with ingestion of milk and antacids. The low PTH level also leads to decreased 1-alpha hydroxylation of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and, therefore, to low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels.

Key learning point: Ingestion of excess calcium leads to phosphorus and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels that are high and low, respectively, relative to the normal ranges.

B) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis causes hypercalcemia by means of increased 1-alpha hydroxylation, such that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels would be high.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid carcinoma would cause elevated levels of PTH and, therefore, low phosphorus levels. Although hypophosphatemia could be masked by renal failure, there should not be low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels in the presence of elevated PTH and adequate 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid adenoma would cause elevated levels of PTH and, therefore, low phosphorus levels. Although hypophosphatemia could be masked by renal failure, there should not be low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels in the presence of elevated PTH and adequate 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels.

E) INCORRECT:

B-cell lymphoma causes hypercalcemia by means of increased 1-alpha hydroxylation, such that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels would be high.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman is evaluated in the clinic for persistent upper abdominal discomfort and bloating for the past year. She describes a burning sensation in her epigastrium unrelated to meals. She has no nausea, vomiting, weight loss, or change in bowel habits. She has tried a proton pump inhibitor daily for three months without significant improvement. She denies any psychiatric history and has normal sleep habits. Physical examination and basic laboratory tests, including complete blood count and liver function tests, are normal (see reports).

Upper endoscopy: No mucosal abnormalities or signs of organic disease
Abdominal ultrasonography: Unremarkable

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Proton pump inhibitor therapy for three more months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The initial upper endoscopy was comprehensive and showed no mucosal abnormalities or signs of organic disease. In the absence of alarm features like weight loss or gastrointestinal bleeding, and with normal laboratory and imaging results, repeating the procedure is unnecessary. The symptoms are more consistent with a functional disorder.

B) CORRECT:

Functional dyspepsia is characterized by chronic upper abdominal discomfort without an identifiable organic cause. Low-dose amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, modulates central pain perception and reduces visceral hypersensitivity, addressing the altered pain processing pathways in this condition. This approach is beneficial for patients unresponsive to acid suppression therapy, as it targets the gut-brain axis dysregulation. Starting at a low dose minimizes side effects while effectively managing symptoms.

Key learning point: In patients with dyspepsia unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors and no evidence of organic disease, functional dyspepsia should be considered, and tricyclic antidepressants can be an effective treatment option.

C) INCORRECT:

A strict elimination diet is considered when symptoms are clearly related to food intake, such as in food allergies or eosinophilic gastroenteritis. This patient's symptoms are unrelated to meals, and her normal endoscopy and ultrasound argue against dietary triggers. Implementing such a diet without evidence of food-induced symptoms may unnecessarily restrict nutrition.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient has already completed a three-month trial of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy without improvement. PPIs are effective for acid-mediated symptoms, but the lack of response suggests a non-acid-related cause. Her negative endoscopy and ultrasound exclude common organic causes, indicating that continuing ineffective PPI therapy is unlikely to address her symptoms.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with seven months of burning epigastric pain, bloating, and early satiety. He denies weight loss, vomiting, or any change in appetite. Physical examination is normal. Blood counts and basic labs are normal. An upper endoscopy performed three weeks ago showed normal mucosa, and Helicobacter pylori testing was negative. He has tried intermittent antacids with little benefit (see report).
Upper endoscopy: Normal mucosa; Helicobacter pylori testing negative
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis usually presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, often with weight loss and steatorrhea. This patient lacks these symptoms and risk factors, such as alcohol use, and has normal lab results and endoscopy, making chronic pancreatitis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori gastritis can cause dyspepsia, but this patient's normal endoscopy and negative H. pylori test exclude this diagnosis. Typical endoscopic findings would include mucosal erythema or nodularity, with biopsies showing chronic inflammation, which are absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastric ulcers present with epigastric pain and are diagnosed by endoscopy showing an ulcerated lesion. This patient's endoscopy showed normal mucosa, excluding a gastric ulcer. The absence of weight loss or vomiting further reduces the likelihood of this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

The patient presents with persistent upper abdominal discomfort, including burning epigastric pain, bloating, and early satiety, with normal laboratory studies and an unremarkable upper endoscopy. These findings, along with negative Helicobacter pylori testing, suggest functional dyspepsia, characterized by dyspeptic symptoms without an organic cause. The Rome IV criteria support this diagnosis, often linked to abnormal gastroduodenal motility and visceral hypersensitivity. Management focuses on symptomatic relief and lifestyle modifications.

Key learning point: Functional dyspepsia is characterized by upper abdominal pain or discomfort without an identifiable cause, and is diagnosed after ruling out other organic causes.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with 2 months of burning epigastric pain, reduced appetite, and an unintentional 5-kg weight loss. He reports occasional nausea but no vomiting. He denies using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Laboratory results show low-normal hemoglobin without other abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to further evaluate his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is effective for evaluating hepatobiliary structures and detecting gallstones or hepatic abnormalities. However, it lacks the resolution to visualize gastric and duodenal mucosa and cannot provide tissue sampling. The patient's symptoms suggest mucosal abnormalities of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making ultrasound an inferior choice for further evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including persistent epigastric pain, unintentional weight loss, and reduced appetite, are alarm features in an individual over 55 years old. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy allows direct visualization of the esophagus, stomach, and proximal duodenum, essential for detecting lesions, ulcers, or early malignancy. It also enables targeted biopsies for histopathological examination, confirming or ruling out significant pathology such as gastric carcinoma or severe peptic ulcer disease. This procedure enhances diagnostic accuracy and supports evidence-based management of suspected serious gastric pathology.

Key learning point: For patients presenting with epigastric pain, weight loss, and loss of appetite, gastroduodenoscopy is the most appropriate investigation as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the upper gastrointestinal tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing for Helicobacter pylori detects antibodies but does not differentiate between past and current infection. It lacks information on mucosal integrity or lesions. In patients over 55 with alarm features like weight loss, direct visualization and tissue diagnosis are needed, making serologic testing insufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study is useful for esophageal structural and motility abnormalities but lacks detailed mucosal visualization and biopsy capability. The patient's symptoms suggest gastric or duodenal pathology, where direct visualization and tissue sampling are necessary, reducing the utility of a barium swallow in this context.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up after being diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. Five weeks ago, you prescribed a 2-week course of antibiotics and omeprazole. He reports feeling well. Which one of the following is most appropriate to confirm treatment success?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because endoscopic follow-up with biopsy (for rapid urease testing) is an invasive procedure, it is only indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication in certain patients with peptic ulcer disease (e.g., to rule out gastric cancer in those with refractory symptoms). This patient should undergo a less invasive procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Stool testing can be used to confirm H. pylori eradication. However, a stool antigen assay rather than a stool culture is indicated. Stool cultures have no role in the management of H. pylori infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Because of increasing antibiotic resistance, eradication should be confirmed in all patients who have been treated for an H. pylori infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing detects IgG antibodies against H. pylori. However, a positive test cannot distinguish between a past and a current infection. Moreover, because H. pylori antibodies may still be present for weeks or months after treatment and eradication, serologic testing has no utility in confirming the success of treatment.

E) CORRECT:

A urea breath test is indicated to confirm H. pylori eradication 4–6 weeks after completing treatment. Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole) should be stopped at least 2 weeks before testing because they increase the risk of false negative results. Other tests for confirming eradication include stool antigen testing and rapid urease testing of biopsy samples. The latter is only considered in patients who require follow-up endoscopy (e.g., those with persistent symptoms, dysplasia on biopsy, new onset of symptoms after successful eradication). Acid suppression medications can be discontinued after eradication is confirmed.

Key learning point: A urea breath test or stool antigen test is recommended 4–6 weeks after H. pylori treatment to confirm eradication, as serology and stool culture are not reliable for this purpose.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of worsening epigastric discomfort and early satiety. She has lost 8 pounds without dieting and reports her grandmother died of stomach cancer. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL, MCV 76 fL, and normal vital signs. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge with proton pump inhibitor therapy
Refer for outpatient H. pylori testing
Discharge with dietary counseling and reassurance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While laboratory studies may be supportive, they do not address the immediate need for endoscopic evaluation in a patient with red flag features of dyspepsia. The presence of weight loss and early satiety requires direct visualization of the upper gastrointestinal tract.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has multiple red flag features of dyspepsia: unintentional weight loss, anemia, and family history of gastrointestinal cancer. These alarm features in a patient under 60 years warrant urgent referral for EGD.

C) INCORRECT:

Outpatient H. pylori testing is appropriate for patients under 60 years without red flag features. However, this patient has unintentional weight loss and iron deficiency anemia, which are red flags requiring endoscopic evaluation rather than noninvasive H. pylori testing.

D) INCORRECT:

There are no indications for inpatient admission in this patient. Another disposition is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and dietary counseling alone are inappropriate when red flag features are present.
